p.seg: The son of Ye gong zi gao (?) had an audience with the chief minister (?) Zi Chun,
Zi Chun told him:
“His majesty is short of men
and appointed me to govern the state of Chu.
I fear I will not be up to it
and that I will suffer the shame of the executioner’s block and cleaver.
the way your father dealt with the duty of criticizing and admonishing (the ruler),
Could you perhaps tell me (something about it) ?
(The son) answered:
“(even though) I have already served in your retinue, observer of the day [and should therefore not dare to advise you],
if you order me to find words to answer,
even if I were to be cut open (myself) on the executioner’s block,
such an order I would not dare to refuse.
As for my view of you, observer of the day,
you are thirteen times better than my deceased father.”
The minister said:
“Your deceased father inherited the office of chief minister
and received that of head of the stables (?),
ruled the government of the state of Chu,
and among the myriad black haired people
none did not rejoice;
within the four seas
none did not trust him.
You say that I am worthier than your father,
may I ask the reason.”
(The son) answered:
“My deceased father’s way of dealing with the government of the state of Chu
was to have five sitting [more intimate?] friends [advisors]
and seven standing [less intimate?] friends [advisors],
whatever the king ordered
nd did in the state of Chu
was necessarily consulted upon internally [=in the inner circle] among the thirteen [the tewlve advisors plus the chief minister]
and if none had misgivings about it,
it would be implemented.
Now you, day observer, have become chief minister of Chu,
and have neither sitting
nor standing advisors,
and yet the government of the state is not crumbling,
that’s why I say
that you, the day observer, are thirteen times better than my father.
